data.text:
What is the course about?

This course is an introduction to four outstanding women philosophers of the 20th century: Mary Midgley (1919-2018), Elizabeth Anscombe (1919-2001), Philippa Foot (1920-2010), and Iris Murdoch (1919-1999).

We will consider their lives in the context of philosophy, and discuss some of their most important philosophical works:

Elizabeth Anscombe: "Intention" (1957). This book, where Anscombe introduces the concept of intention, is considered one of her most significant contributions to philosophy.

Mary Midgley: "Evolution as a Religion" (1985). In this work, Midgley criticises the way evolution is sometimes treated as a kind of secular religion or worldview.

Philippa Foot: "Natural Goodness" (2001). Foot outlines her version of virtue ethics in this book, which becomes a central pillar in her philosophical thought.

Iris Murdoch: "Metaphysics as a Guide to Morals" (1992). Murdoch provides a broad and nuanced exploration of moral philosophy and the influence of metaphysical beliefs on moral thought in this work.

What will we cover?

We will cover a range of central philosophical questions to which these four philosophers have made significant contributions as highlighted above.

What will I achieve?

By the end of this course you should be able to...

Engage in an informed discussion about the lives and philosophical work of these outstanding women philosophers and be in a position to continue more advanced study of their philosophy.

What level is the course and do I need any particular skills?

This is an introductory course and does not require any prior study. An open mind and a willingness to listen to and think about views with which you do not always agree are more important than specific levels of skills.

How will I be taught, and will there be any work outside the class?

The course will be taught in person and no work outside the class is required.

Are there any other costs? Is there anything I need to bring?

No; you may want to take notes for future reference. A list of recommended reading for further study will be provided at the end of the course.
